column1: HUT 8 RIVERBEND DATA CENTER - WORK BREAKDOWN STRUCTURE (WBS)
Project: Hut 8 Riverbend Data Center - 224 MW Facility
Scope: Switchyard Commissioning (May-Jul 2026) + Block 1 Data Hall Commissioning (Aug-Sep 2026)
STAFFING MODEL - TWO FULLY REDUNDANT CREWS

Direct oversight and execution of mechanical system commissioning

Program oversight across all blocks. Oversees and directs all L4/L5 commissioning activities. Vendor coordination, client interface, issue resolution
Documentation QA/QC, report generation, data management, scheduling support across all blocks
Cx Manager: 50 hrs/week + Doc Coordinator: 25 hrs/week = 75 hrs/week
Maximum weekly hours when both crews active: 1075 hrs/week
Weekly hours when single crew active: 575 hrs/week

column14: Dependencies / Notes
Critical path for all data hall commissioning
Crew mobilization, safety orientation, site access, test equipment setup
Review design documents, equipment submittals, O&M manuals, coordination studies, protection settings. Memorial Day May 26.
Physical verification of equipment installation, nameplate verification, anchor bolts, grounding, clearances, cable terminations
Oversight of GC-performed pre-functional testing. Witness point-to-point checks, control sequences, interlocks, safeties

Functional testing of utility interconnection equipment. Transformer testing (IR, turns ratio, power factor), relay testing (primary/secondary injection), breaker timing, SCADA integration. Independence Day July 4.
Utility witness testing, acceptance, initial energization coordination. Phased energization to 300 MW capacity.
Final documentation, issue resolution, punch list closeout, commissioning report, turnover to Owner
Both Crew A and Crew B deployed for entire switchyard phase. 12 weeks × 1,075 hrs/week = 12,900 hours

column7: Insulation resistance, turns ratio, power factor, temperature rise, relay testing
Relay testing, coordination verification, interlocks, SCADA integration, metering accuracy
Primary/secondary injection testing, breaker timing, contact resistance, insulation resistance, operational sequences
Settings verification, coordination study validation, primary injection testing, communications testing
Integration testing, data accuracy, alarming, trending, remote monitoring

column1: Note: Switchyard equipment list to be confirmed via RFI-001.07 (CRITICAL question - switchyard scope ambiguous in RFP)

column6: Site: 12,000 hours | Management: 900 hours | Total: 12,900 hours

column1: PHASE 1: BLOCK 1 (DH-1) DATA HALL COMMISSIONING (AUGUST - SEPTEMBER 2026)

column14: Dependencies / Notes
First data hall block. Includes Network Room L1-3 oversight.
Block 1 commissioning startup. Site familiarization, test equipment setup specific to data hall. Both crews active for startup.
Review Block 1 equipment submittals, O&M manuals, test procedures. Single crew adequate. Crew B on standby.
Physical verification of Block 1 equipment installation. Nameplate verification, grounding checks, clearances. Single crew adequate.
Oversight of GC-performed pre-functional testing for Block 1. Witness point-to-point checks, control sequences. Single crew adequate.
Block 1 L4 functional testing startup. Transformer testing, switchboard testing, UPS functional testing begins. Labor Day Sep 1.

Continued L4 functional testing: UPS (113 units), batteries (351 cabinets), chillers (27), CDUs (32), CRAH units (47 total), rack power panels (160), all electrical and mechanical systems. Single crew adequate for steady-state testing.
Block 1 L5 IST startup. Both crews active for integration testing. Electrical system integration, mechanical system integration, load bank testing coordination begins.

Continued L5 IST: Heat load testing with load banks (provided by others, PGCIS oversight), failure scenario testing, emergency procedures (EPO), monitoring system integration (BMS/EPMS/DCIM), N+1 verification.
Final punch list resolution, documentation package completion, Owner acceptance, turnover. Included in L5 Week 2 hours.
Crew A: 7 weeks active | Crew B: 2 weeks active (startup + L5) | Average 17.1 site staff

Functional testing, breaker coordination, monitoring, feeder verification
Flow/pressure testing, temperature differential verification, control sequences, leak testing. Pressure test/flush/fill by others, PGCIS oversight.
Airflow measurement and balancing, control integration, VFD testing, staging sequences. TAB by others, PGCIS oversight.
Complete electrical system load testing, transfer scenarios, N+1 verification, failure mode testing
Integrated cooling system performance, load following, economizer modes, redundancy verification
Heat load testing with load banks (provided/operated by others): Ramp testing, steady-state, cooling response, power quality. PGCIS plan review and oversight.
Full facility monitoring integration: alarms, trending, remote monitoring, control sequences. CxAlloy or Facility Grid platform.
Emergency scenarios: EPO testing, utility failure, cooling failure, UPS transfer

column1: Standby Definition: Crew is not actively deployed on-site but remains available for:

column2: - Emergency support if Block 1 experiences critical deficiencies or delays
- Surge capacity during punch list resolution or retest activities
- Preparation activities for upcoming Block 2 commissioning (mobilization begins Week 18)
- Other PGCIS project support as needed

column10: Network Room equipment commissioning performed by GC under PGCIS oversight. Concurrent with Block 1 Weeks 1-6. Hours included in Block 1 labor totals.

column1: Network Room L4-5 commissioning (if required) would be separate scope - not included in Block 1 WBS.

column2: 1. Switchyard commissioning is critical path - must complete before Block 1 start (RFI-001.07 CRITICAL question)
2. Two fully redundant 10-person crews provide schedule flexibility and risk mitigation
3. Both crews active during: Switchyard (12 weeks)
4. Single crew (Crew A) adequate for Block 1 L1-L4 steady-state activities (Weeks 2-5 of Block 1)
5. Crew B on standby during Block 1 Weeks 2-5: Available for surge support or Block 2 preparation
6. Cx Manager provides continuous program oversight (hybrid/remote) - full-time across all phases
7. Documentation Coordinator (50%) supports centrally (hybrid/remote) - all phases
8. Labor hours assume: Equipment energized and L3 complete per schedule
9. TAB and pressure testing performed by others - PGCIS oversight and documentation review only
10. Load banks provided and operated by others - PGCIS plan review and oversight only
11. Network Room L1-3 oversight concurrent with Block 1 - hours included in Block 1 totals

column5: Switchyard is absolute critical path. Any delay cascades to all data halls. Dual crew deployment accelerates schedule.
Weather-dependent outdoor work. Plan indoor backup activities during weather delays.
GC must complete installation. PGCIS oversight ensures quality before L4.
Functional testing of utility interconnection. Specialized HV testing required.
Utility coordination required. Energization schedule outside PGCIS control.
Block 1 cannot start without energized utility power from switchyard.
Crew A leads with Crew B support at startup.
GC must complete pre-functional testing. Single crew oversight adequate.
L4 cannot start until equipment energized and L3 substantially complete. 5 weeks required, single crew adequate.
Both crews required for integrated systems testing. Load banks must be available.

column1: Critical Path Summary: Switchyard (12 weeks) → Block 1 L1-L4 (6 weeks) → Block 1 L5 (2 weeks) = 20 weeks total (May - October 2026)

column5: Aggressive coordination, early utility engagement, dual crew acceleration capability
Build 1-week weather contingency into switchyard schedule
RFI-001.07 CRITICAL question must be answered before pricing finalized

column4: L4 start delayed - cascades through Block 1
column5: Dual crew model allows surge support, early GC coordination, contractual L3 completion requirements
15% contingency built in; dual crews provide surge capacity for retest
Pre-schedule vendor support 4-6 weeks in advance, dual crews can work around vendor delays
Contractually require load banks from Owner/others, confirm availability 6 weeks before L5

column4: Labor Day during Block 1 L4 startup
column5: Minimal impact - single holiday. Adjust startup to avoid Sep 1 if feasible.

column1: Overall Risk: MEDIUM-HIGH for Switchyard (critical path + scope ambiguity). MEDIUM for Block 1 (standard commissioning risks with dual crew mitigation).

Progress updates, issues log, schedule status, photos. Submitted every Friday.

Deficiency tracking with photos and resolution status
Final switchyard commissioning report including all test results, certifications, utility acceptance documentation
Final Block 1 commissioning report including executive summary, all test results, training records, O&M manuals, warranty documentation
Operator training on systems and O&M procedures
Complete documentation package: reports, test data, issues log, training records, warranties, O&M manuals, as-built drawings
